solution.text:
Let a be the first term and r be the common ratio of the G.P.
\(a_1=a,a_2=ar,a_3=ar^2,a_4=ar^3\)
By the given condition,
\(a_3=a_1+_{{p*q**2 - p}}_=ar^2=a+_{{p*q**2 - p}}_\) ........(1)
\(a_2=a_4+_{{p*q - p*q**3}}_=ar=ar^3+_{{p*q - p*q**3}}_\) ......(2)
From (1) and (2), we obtain
\(a(r^2-1)=_{{p*q**2 - p}}_\) ........(3)
\(ar(1-r^2)=_{{p*q - p*q**3}}_\) ..........(4)
Dividing (4) by (3), we obtain
\(\frac{ar(1-r^2)}{a(r^2-1)}=\frac{_{{p*q - p*q**3}}_}{_{{p*q**2 - p}}_}\)
r=_{q}_
Substituting the value of r in (1), we obtain
\(_{{q**2}}_a=a+_{{p*q**2 - p}}_\)
\(_{{q**2-1}}_a=_{{p*q**2 - p}}_\)
\(a=_{p}_\)
Thus, second term will be
\(ar=_{{p*q}}_\)

content.text: Find second term of a geometric progression in which third term is greater than the first term by _{{p*q**2 - p}}_ , and the second term is greater than the 4th by _{{p*q - p*q**3}}_ .
